description:
Dinosaur Ridge (also more correctly known as Dakota Ridge) was sliced in half with the construction of the I70 freeway. This trail extends along the top of the northern portion of that ridge.
After a short trek up to the top of the ridge from the trailhead, the trail reaches the base of a high-voltage transmission tower and continues northwards along the ridgeline. 
Meandering between short and gnarled pines, this section of the trail unfortunately runs parallel to the I70 freeway, is within eyesight of a law enforcement shooting range, a popular dirtbike track and a mining facility. 
Needless to say, it is NOISY, and almost completely destroys the atmosphere. Fortunately however, the geology of the area is quite interesting - rocky outcroppings and immense boulders scatter the ridgeline, and a few excavation sites from old clay mines and dinosaur removal sites expose some of the truly unique features that give this ridge its name: an immense wall of fossilized ocean bottom ripples can be quite distinctly seen in a massive cut leftover from an old mining site. the wildflower population is quite colourful as well: wild penstemon, wild rosebushes and a number of other varieties of wildflower scatter the hillside.
The Ridge unfortunately is higher at the southern end than the northern end, so the return trip is something of an uphill battle. The grade however is quite light. An easy hike.
One warning of note: Because this ridge was extensively mined, there are pitfalls which at times border the trail's edge. If your children or pets are prone to darting off suddenly, it may be a good idea to keep them on a short leash. In addition, in the large excavation site where the large wall of ripple formations can be found, there is an old mine shaft which has been covered over by a massive metal grille. I highly recommend 
avoiding that area for no reason other than due prudence. 
There is also an interpretive boardwalk at this site with designated 1-
hour parking, however, at the time of this writing there has been some 
severe vandalism of the first four interpretive signs. Several have been 
spray painted with graffiti a few layers thick, and a couple have been 
punctured. I still recommend checking out the path; its only a few 
hundred meters and you really get to see some interesting formations. 
The asphalt path has also been poorly maintained and has been layered 
over in places by mud eroded from the hillside.
directions:
Heading west on I70, take exit 259 and proceed right at the first intersection. A large parking lot for commuters has been established there, and the trailhead for the hike departs from the parking lot as well. Look for a small yellow hatched triangle near the trailhead.
The interpretive boardwalk is on the same side as the freeway, whereas the trail is on the side facing away from the freeway.
title: North Dinosaur Ridge
